title: How to Make Fake Body Jewelry

steps.headline: Wrap a paperclip around a pencil.
steps.description: Use a clean and new silver paperclip. Wrap the paperclip around a pencil or thin, round paintbrush handle. Wrapping the paperclip should create a smooth loop. It’s best to use a silver paperclip because the color may rub off if it has been coated in paint.

steps.headline: Trim off the excess metal.
steps.description: Use a pair of wire cutters to trim off the excess metal. Make sure to leave enough of the loop for the septum ring to fit comfortably on your septum. Try on the ring as you cut it down if you aren’t sure how large it needs to be.

steps.headline: Sand the rough edges of the metal.
steps.description: The wire cutters will likely leave rough edges, which will hurt the inside of your nose. Use a file or sandpaper to smooth out the edges. Try it on to make sure it isn’t too uncomfortable.

steps.headline: Put on the fake septum ring.
steps.description: First, disinfect the ring by quickly washing it with soap and water or wiping it with a cloth soaked in rubbing alcohol. Then, gently pull the ring open, creating more space in between the ends. Insert one side of the ring into each side of the septum cartilage. Finish by gently squeezing the ring so that it will stay once you start moving around.

steps.headline: Add a few small beads to the ring (optional).
steps.description: If you don’t want to decorate the ring, you don’t have to. But, a few small beads will add a decorative element to your septum ring. Choose three very small silver or colored beads. Thread them onto the ring. If you want to make sure they will stay, glue them down with a clear adhesive. You can use hot glue to adhere the beads to the loop.

steps.headline: Reuse the ring until it starts showing signs of wear.
steps.description: It’s okay to reuse the septum ring. Stop using it when you start to see signs of discoloration on the metal or other signs of wear (like breakage). Make sure to clean the ring with soap and water or rubbing alcohol before each use.

steps.headline: Remove the bar from a cartilage hoop earring.
steps.description: It is possible to keep the bar on, but this will be very uncomfortable when it comes time to put the ring on your lip. So, use a pair of wire cutters to remove the bar. Make sure that you snap off the bar all the way.

steps.headline: File down the rough metal edges.
steps.description: The newly exposed metal will be rough and uncomfortable. Use a file or sandpaper to make the metal smooth. Run your finger over the metal when you’re done to make sure it is completely smooth.

steps.headline: Wash the earring thoroughly.
steps.description: It is not sanitary to immediately put the fake lip ring in your mouth, so wash it when you’re done filing the metal. Use water and soap on it. You can use your fingers to rub the soap onto the loop or you can apply it with a towel. Rinse the ring off with water when you are finished washing it.

steps.headline: Place the ring on your lip.
steps.description: Put the lip on the whichever side of your mouth you’d like it to be on. Typically, the lip ring should be worn on the bottom lip. Put on end of the ring on the inside of your lip and the other end of the ring on the outside of your lip. The ring should be vertical on your lip.

steps.headline: Tighten the ring to your lip.
steps.description: Use a pair of pliers to gently tighten it to your lip. If you do not have pliers, it’s okay to use your fingers as long as they have been washed. The ring should feel comfortable, but it needs to stay in as you move around.

steps.headline: Choose material for your earring.
steps.description: A good choice is to use a stud that has a bar with two balls on either end because the material is sturdy. You can also use a short piece of thick metal wire. If you don’t have a metal wire you can straighten a piece of a paper clip and cut off a portion of it.

steps.headline: Bend the metal into a hoop with a pair of pliers.
steps.description: Use a pair of pliers to gently bend the ring. Take your time as you do this or you may break the stud. Patiently bend the ring until you have a hoop. If you’re using metal wire, it won’t take as much effort to create hoop, but you should still be careful during the process to avoid breakage.

steps.headline: Use a skin-friendly adhesive glue to attach the stud.
steps.description: Use a strong, but skin-friendly adhesive glue to attach the ring to your eyebrow. You can find this type of glue at an arts and crafts store, costume shop, or at some cosmetic stores. Put a dab of glue on either end of the loop before application. For glue removal, scrub with a mineral or baby oil. It’s also an option to purchase a solvent made specifically for removing skin-friendly adhesive glue.

steps.headline: Apply the eyebrow loop.
steps.description: First, wash off the loop with soap and water and dry it. Then, put one end of the loop towards the end of the eyebrow. One side of the loop should be above the eyebrow and the other end below the eyebrow. Hold the ring in place for a moment as you wait for the glue to dry. You can reuse the ring until you start to see signs of wear, such as discoloration or breakage. Wash the ring before each use.

steps.headline: Apply a 3-D sticker around your eyebrow.
steps.description: If you don’t want a hoop, you can use 3-D sticker as “studs.” Use two 3-D stickers in the color of your choice. Apply one sticker just above the middle to end of your eyebrows. Then, apply another sticker directly below on the other side of your eyebrow. A 3-D sticker can also be used as a nose ring.

text: Creating a Septum Ring Wrap a paperclip around a pencil. Use a clean and new silver paperclip. Wrap the paperclip around a pencil or thin, round paintbrush handle. Wrapping the paperclip should create a smooth loop. It’s best to use a silver paperclip because the color may rub off if it has been coated in paint. Trim off the excess metal. Use a pair of wire cutters to trim off the excess metal. Make sure to leave enough of the loop for the septum ring to fit comfortably on your septum. Try on the ring as you cut it down if you aren’t sure how large it needs to be. Sand the rough edges of the metal. The wire cutters will likely leave rough edges, which will hurt the inside of your nose. Use a file or sandpaper to smooth out the edges. Try it on to make sure it isn’t too uncomfortable. Put on the fake septum ring. First, disinfect the ring by quickly washing it with soap and water or wiping it with a cloth soaked in rubbing alcohol. Then, gently pull the ring open, creating more space in between the ends. Insert one side of the ring into each side of the septum cartilage. Finish by gently squeezing the ring so that it will stay once you start moving around. Add a few small beads to the ring (optional). If you don’t want to decorate the ring, you don’t have to. But, a few small beads will add a decorative element to your septum ring. Choose three very small silver or colored beads. Thread them onto the ring. If you want to make sure they will stay, glue them down with a clear adhesive. You can use hot glue to adhere the beads to the loop. Reuse the ring until it starts showing signs of wear. It’s okay to reuse the septum ring. Stop using it when you start to see signs of discoloration on the metal or other signs of wear (like breakage). Make sure to clean the ring with soap and water or rubbing alcohol before each use. Crafting a Lip Ring Remove the bar from a cartilage hoop earring. It is possible to keep the bar on, but this will be very uncomfortable when it comes time to put the ring on your lip. So, use a pair of wire cutters to remove the bar. Make sure that you snap off the bar all the way. File down the rough metal edges. The newly exposed metal will be rough and uncomfortable. Use a file or sandpaper to make the metal smooth. Run your finger over the metal when you’re done to make sure it is completely smooth. Wash the earring thoroughly. It is not sanitary to immediately put the fake lip ring in your mouth, so wash it when you’re done filing the metal. Use water and soap on it. You can use your fingers to rub the soap onto the loop or you can apply it with a towel. Rinse the ring off with water when you are finished washing it. Place the ring on your lip. Put the lip on the whichever side of your mouth you’d like it to be on. Typically, the lip ring should be worn on the bottom lip. Put on end of the ring on the inside of your lip and the other end of the ring on the outside of your lip. The ring should be vertical on your lip. Tighten the ring to your lip. Use a pair of pliers to gently tighten it to your lip. If you do not have pliers, it’s okay to use your fingers as long as they have been washed. The ring should feel comfortable, but it needs to stay in as you move around. Making an Eyebrow Ring Choose material for your earring. A good choice is to use a stud that has a bar with two balls on either end because the material is sturdy. You can also use a short piece of thick metal wire. If you don’t have a metal wire you can straighten a piece of a paper clip and cut off a portion of it. Bend the metal into a hoop with a pair of pliers. Use a pair of pliers to gently bend the ring. Take your time as you do this or you may break the stud. Patiently bend the ring until you have a hoop. If you’re using metal wire, it won’t take as much effort to create hoop, but you should still be careful during the process to avoid breakage. Use a skin-friendly adhesive glue to attach the stud. Use a strong, but skin-friendly adhesive glue to attach the ring to your eyebrow. You can find this type of glue at an arts and crafts store, costume shop, or at some cosmetic stores. Put a dab of glue on either end of the loop before application. For glue removal, scrub with a mineral or baby oil. It’s also an option to purchase a solvent made specifically for removing skin-friendly adhesive glue. Apply the eyebrow loop. First, wash off the loop with soap and water and dry it. Then, put one end of the loop towards the end of the eyebrow. One side of the loop should be above the eyebrow and the other end below the eyebrow. Hold the ring in place for a moment as you wait for the glue to dry. You can reuse the ring until you start to see signs of wear, such as discoloration or breakage. Wash the ring before each use. Apply a 3-D sticker around your eyebrow. If you don’t want a hoop, you can use 3-D sticker as “studs.” Use two 3-D stickers in the color of your choice. Apply one sticker just above the middle to end of your eyebrows. Then, apply another sticker directly below on the other side of your eyebrow. A 3-D sticker can also be used as a nose ring.
